review: I'm a dyed in the wool Apple TV user. I have pretty much nailed down everything Apple - it makes life easy when everything is on one platform. This device has made me question everything, here's why...I use Apple TV for: - Hulu Plus - Netflix - Movies, TV on-demand, streaming - Accessing my video libraryFire TV does all of these except access my video library, as it doesn't offer DLNA support. Neither device offers Spotify, which is what I typically use. The huge upside to Fire TV, the interface is easy and FAST. The delay I get on Apple TV drives me crazy, and it's been that way since the first silver colored Apple TVs with the internal hard drives.For a while I'm going to be dependent on Apple TV to access my mpeg4 video library. If Amazon comes up with a DLNA solution and even Spotify, I would consider a move over.Here's the dilemma - the Fire TV is a hardcore Apple TV competitor, and it competes with what Apple TV is now. Apple is 12 months away from a new release which will likely offer improved content and hardware, and a significant overhaul. I'm guessing they will combine the airport express into their set-top-box configuration. When this happens, Amazon and Roku will be playing catch up again. It's the same in the phone world for the most part, although the margin is narrowing!

author: Justin B.

review: Well, this is basically what I wanted from the Google TV that was released several years ago; a easily hackable console that ran on the TV. When Google released that, they kept claiming they'd release an SDK, and ultimately never did. Amazon delivers a nice development environment out of the box.One awesome feature is that you can directly connect to adb server on the device over wifi without needing a long USB running from your desktop / laptop to the device. Coupled with the fact the device is always powered (so no fear of finding the thing uncharged after leaving it alone for a few days), it's one of the nicest Android development experiences I've had (I really hate USB cables). The only draw back is that it seems that at the moment, the SDK does not give you direct access to the raw audio stream of the microphone.As for the typical use case (watching videos) this works really well. Note the Instant Video may not work as advertised, but if it doesn't, it's because of your Internet Provider. I had Comcast, and after switching to a local internet Provider (Yay condo internet) the Instant Video worked amazingly well. It actually had the problem that it was too fast; audio would start half a second before the video (mostly only noticeable when resuming a video from the carousel).

Pretty much instantly, when you put batteries in the remote, it talks to you and you setup your wifi.  You need your password.  I already have Prime so it just automatically had my Watch List and movies I was watching saved.  Brain Dead easy.  And the picture is fabulous with this.  No buffering time.  Use with Netflix, too.  You will love it.

review: I've owned my Fire TV for a few weeks and I won't go back to navigating online apps through my blu-ray player.The Pros:- The unit is fast, much faster than my blu-ray player utilizing the same internet connection. Shows load faster.- The unit it tiny. Most people would never even notice the box sitting beside my TV.- The interface is very intuitive.- The remote is so simple, reminds me of a wii remote but smaller. No excessive buttons.- The voice search works great for amazon.- Both the wired and wireless internet connections work flawlessly.The Cons:- The voice search needs to work across all applications, especially Netflix.- Need to more easily distinguish or be able to select for it to only display amazon prime streaming shows, without all the purchase options.
